Matt in Falls Church -

I believe that you are incorrect about Rasmussen's inclusion in the swing state results. Using Ohio as an example, note that the model was updated at 12:43AM on 3 Nov but Nate's blog was last updated at 9:33AM, almost 9 hours later.

This most likely means that Ramussen's 2 Nov poll of Ohio (listed in the text of the blog as a tie) wasn't available for the model runs the previous evening. Rasmussen is represented in the model most recently by their 28 Oct poll, which had Romney up 2, although the weight was lowered (probably due to the time elapsed since the poll was taken).

If the Ohio results from the model had included the 3 Nov Rasmussen poll, presumably with a somewhat higher weight since the results were "fresh", the outcome would have been a bit WORSE for Romney, not better.

The other state mentioned in the blog text as having a fresh Rasmussen poll is Michigan (where I live); it has Obama up 5, which is in line with most of the other recent polls taken here.

Michigan, of course, is not widely considered to be "in play" at the national level, although the Romney campaign is running quite a bit of advertising here (I live in the middle of the state, too far from the Ohio border for our local TV market to reach, and our senate race looks pretty safe for the Democratic incumbent, so my best guess is that the Romney campaign and associated PACs have so much money that they don't know what else to do with it).

Mr. Romney has failed to make the case for his election and Mr. Douthat cannot make up for Mr. Romney's failures.

You are certainly right about rebuilding in hazard zones and the political difficulties in trying to avoid it. Look no further than New Orleans for an example.

Living in eastern North Carolina, where the highest point in Carteret County is about 25 feet asl, there is a huge debate ongoing about climate change, sea level rise, and development in flood zones.

North Carolina has a good coastal management law that makes it very difficult, if not impossible to develop on the natural shoreline or within 100 feet of it. I live on the soundfront, and I cannot stick a shovel in the ground within 75 feet of the shoreline without a permit. Permits in coastal areas are limited to typical, low impact maritime structures such as docks, piers and boat lifts. Forget any kind of hardened structure or barrier. Of course, grandfathering has perpetuated some structures, but if they are damaged more than 50% in a storm they cannot be replaced.

I don't know whether NY or NJ has a coastal management law, but such an approach to coastal development can be most helpful. Even die-hard developer types and libertarians agree with the utility of it. The regulatory regime has virtually universal support except among development interests that can't see the big picture.

Of course, many serious issues arise, such as property taking and other constitutional questions. But they can be managed, and it's a reasonable price to pay to get acceptable building in coastal areas.

In previous articles, Nate has written that state polls have historically done better than national polls as predictors of the election.
State polls may indeed be biased in Obama's favor; that's why Nate's model gives Romney a roughly 15% chance of winning.

Nate has discussed the discrepancy between state and national polls no less than 3 or 4 times. He is fully aware of it and has priced it into his model. Now if you are asking if his model works, well we'll all have to wait till Tuesday to find out.

Here's my latest worry.

With the current snapshot, 16.3% of the time the poll data we have will be found to be biased enough to give Mitt Romney a win.

However, we also have a discrepancy between state and national polls, with the state polls leaning more heavily toward Obama and the national polls calling a very close race. Doesn't the very existence of this type of discrepancy increase the chances that the state polls are biased in Obama's favor?

I'd like to introduce the idea for a new law regarding journalism: Journalistic Slander.

Journalistic Slander is the attempt to misinform a public under the guise of journalistic information - or - the broadcast of information that was false, or intended to make an impression that was false, where the journalist knew it was false or SHOULD HAVE KNOWN (if you are paid to inform the public, you do minimum due diligence).

When Sara Pallin was working for Fox News, and "informed" the public that "end of life counseling" was the introduction of a form of death panels she was blatantly attempting to misinform the public, to rush against the idea, even though it wasn't a 'death panel' and the implementation of end of life counseling was in the best interest of the listener. She was misinforming the public.

Now, if Ms. Pallin unintentionally got it wrong, after reasonable investigation, no foul. But if it was found that she purposely misrepresented the information for a public audience, then she should be fined, sent to jail, and be subject to a tort brought against her by any listener who suffered accordingly.

Studies have shown that Fox News viewers are less informed than people who never watch the news. All those viewers ought to have a right to bring a tort against Fox for making them stupider. All those involved from Murdock to the presenter (Hannity) should do hard time.

This is important to the country. It wasn't a well informed public that voted Hitler into power.

b.,
Do you think that a politician's personal finances have no relevance to their public service? If so, I disagree. I don't think past financial difficulties necessarily disqualify someone from office (in general, I think we have the opposite problem, that our representatives are too wealthy to be representative; I commend Mr. Lieber for trying to identify whether it's just that we only ever read about the wealthy ones). Anyone can have bad luck, and climbing out of that situation demonstrates a certain fortitude. I can also imagine that a Congressman who has, for example, gone through foreclosure would bring that perspective to their legislating. But someone who's demonstrated a sequential inability to manage their personal finances is worrisome, when they achieved office on the basis of their party's platform of responsible spending. I also don't see any particular indication that Mr. Walsh has brought any new thinking to the problems of how to help those caught in the recent crash. Finally, I can't help noting that there is a segment of Republican voter which equates wealth with morality - so how do they justify in their own minds elevating someone in Mr. Walsh's financial situation to national office?
Can a president of the United States keep his billions of dollars stashed in off-shore low-tax countries?
